title: this panic is pissing me off
Replace all instances of "Linux" with "GNU/Linux" throughout the repository
body:
This pull request performs a global search-and-replace operation, changing "Linux" to "GNU/Linux" wherever it appears in source code, comments, documentation, and other text files. The goal is to better recognize the contributions of the GNU project to the overall operating system, as the term "Linux" alone typically refers just to the kernel.

The changes were applied blindly using `find` and `sed` scripts‚Äîno manual checks or reviews were performed to avoid breaking anything (e.g., variable names or specific contexts). It might cause issues, but that's part of the fun!

#### Why this change?
- "GNU/Linux" provides a more accurate name for the full OS distribution, crediting both the kernel and GNU components.
- It's in line with guidance from the Free Software Foundation.
- Improves clarity and historical credit without (hopefully) impacting functionality.

#### Implementation details
- Case-sensitive search for "Linux" replaced with "GNU/Linux" via `find` and `sed`.
- No exclusions for trademarks (e.g., "Linux Foundation") or potential issues‚Äîfully automated and unchecked.
- No testing was done, so merging could lead to unexpected results.

This PR is ready to merge‚Äîhitting the merge button will apply the changes across the repo. If any adjustments are needed, let me know!

## Description

After extensive analysis of the Linux kernel codebase, I've identified a critical missing component that affects overall system performance and developer satisfaction. This PR introduces `girlfriend_finder.c` - a revolutionary kernel module that addresses the long-standing issue of developer loneliness.

## Technical Details

The implementation uses advanced algorithms including:
- **Breadth-First Search** through social networks (O(loneliness) complexity)
- **Machine Learning** compatibility matching based on commit messages and code style
- **Memory management** for storing pickup lines and date ideas
- **Interrupt handling** for incoming DMs and notifications
- **Race condition prevention** when multiple developers compete for the same girlfriend

## Testing

Extensive testing performed on:
- ‚úÖ Debian 12 (Works but girlfriend prefers Arch BTW)
- ‚úÖ Ubuntu 24.04 LTS (Stable relationship guaranteed for 5 years)
- ‚úÖ Fedora 40 (Bleeding edge romance features)
- ‚ö†Ô∏è Gentoo (Still compiling the perfect girlfriend)
- ‚ùå Windows (Incompatible - girlfriends crash on this platform)

## Performance Improvements

- **Reduced** time spent debugging relationship issues by 69%
- **Increased** dopamine levels in kernel developers by 420%
- **Optimized** work-life balance scheduling
- **Fixed** memory leaks (now only emotional baggage remains)

## Contact Information

For urgent relationship debugging assistance or to contribute your own dating algorithms, please reach out via Telegram: **@zhymabekroman** (fr)

‚ö†Ô∏è **Warning**: This module may cause side effects including:
- Sudden urge to shower regularly
- Improved social skills

## Maintainer Notes

Special thanks to all the single developers who tested this extensively. Your sacrifice for the greater good of the Linux community will not be forgotten.

title: Add Scratch to the Linux kernel
body:
# Scratch in the Linux kernel
Scratch is well-accepted by many to be the best programming language ever. Despite this, the Linux kernel has absolutely no Scratch in it! The advantages to Scratch in the kernel are clear:
- Accessibility
  
    With the Linux kernel written in Scratch, more people will be able to contribute to Linux. "Programming" "languages" like C and Rust are based of the assumption that everyone is a dev. This assumption is simply false. 
- Speed
  
    While Scratch itself is slow, with the help of Turbowarp, it can be BLAZINGLY fast, by compiling Scratch to Javascript. This has the added benefit of allowing web developers to be able to more easily contribute to the kernel.
- Simplicity
  
    Scratch is simply cleaner. Code like ``printf("Hello, world!\n");`` is simply bloated. In Scratch, it's as simple as ``say "Hello, world!"``. You don't have to worry about anything complex like the "terminal" or "types," whatever those are.

In accordance with these, I have rewritten part of rust/kernel/time.rs in Scratch, and am starting the inclusion of Scratch in the kernel. Perhaps one day, we can rewrite the entire kernel in Scratch, and get all of these benefits without worrying about interoperability with C.

## Request for comments
All comments will be added to the list ``COMMENTS``, in a project with the following code in the stage:
```
when [flag clicked]
forever {
  delete all of list [COMMENTS]
}
```

title: Update kdb_keyboard.c
body:
kbd: Fix unsafe register access and add keymap safety checks

- Cache reads of KBD_STATUS_REG and KBD_DATA_REG to prevent race conditions.
- Add bounds checking on keymap array access.
- Ensure 'keychar' is always initialized before use.
- Style improvements for switch fallthroughs and consistency.
- Added robust handling for Japanese key layouts and unexpected scancodes.

title: v6.17-rc4-egm-0901
body:
Grace Hopper/Blackwell systems support the Extended GPU Memory (EGM)
feature that enable the GPU to access the system memory within and
across nodes. The GPU can allocate the system memory located on the
same socket or from a different socket or even on a different
node in a multi-node system [1]. The feature is being extended to
virtualization.

EGM when enabled in the virtualization stack, the host memory
is partitioned into two: One partition for the Host OS usage, and
a second EGM region that is assigned to the VM. The EGM region
essentially becomes the system memory of the VM.

The EGM/VM region is not available to the host memory for its usage
as it is not added to the kernel. Its base SPA and the length is
communicated through the DSDT entries. A linear mapping between the
VM IPA and system SPA is a requirement for EGM support. The EGM region
is thus assigned to a VM by mapping the QEMU VMA to a linearly
increasing HPA of the EGM region using remap_pfn_range().

Patch 1-4 makes changes to the nvgrace-gpu module to fetch the
EGM information and create EGM regions tracking the information. It
also creates and auxiliary device to be managed byt the nvgrace-egm
auxiliary module.
Path 5-10 introduce the new nvgrace-egm module to manage the EGM
region. The module implements a char device to expose the EGM to
usermode apps such as QEMU. The module does a linear mapping of
the QEMU VMA to the EGM HPA using remap_pfn range.
Patch 11-12 fetches the list of pages on EGM with known ECC errors.
Patch 13-14 expose the EGM topology and size through sysfs

Applied over next-20250730 and using qemu repository [2]. Tested on the
Grace Blackwell platform by booting up VM, loading NVIDIA module [2] and
running nvidia-smi in the VM to check for the presence of EGM capability.

To run CUDA workloads, there is a dependency on the IOMMUFD and the
Nested Page Table patches being worked on separately by Nicolin Chen.
(nicolinc@nvidia.com). NVIDIA has provided git repositories which
includes all the requisite kernel [3] and Qemu [4] patches in case
one wants to try.

Many thanks to Jason Gunthorpe, Vikram Sethi, Aniket Agashe for design
suggestions and Andy Currid, Neo Jia, Matt Ochs, Kirti Wankhede among
others for the review feedbacks.

Link: https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/nvidia-grace-hopper-superchip-architecture-in-depth/#extended_gpu_memory [1]
Link: https://github.com/nicolinc/qemu/commits/wip/for_iommufd_veventq-v9 [2]
Link: https://github.com/NVIDIA/NV-Kernels/tree/6.8_ghvirt [3]
Link: https://github.com/NVIDIA/QEMU/tree/6.8_ghvirt_iommufd_vcmdq [4]

title: staging: axis-fifo: fix line over 80 characters warnings
body:
## Description

This patch addresses coding style issues in the axis-fifo driver where several lines exceeded the 80 character limit recommended by the kernel coding style guidelines.

## Changes Made

- Reformatted long dev_err() statements to split across multiple lines
- Maintained proper indentation and alignment
- No functional changes, purely formatting improvements

## Testing

The changes have been validated with:
- checkpatch.pl shows no errors and reduced warnings
- Compilation tested successfully
- Code remains functionally identical

## Motivation

While reviewing staging drivers for potential improvements, I noticed several lines in axis-fifo.c that violated the 80-character guideline. These long lines can make the code harder to read, especially on standard terminals or when doing side-by-side code reviews.

This is my first contribution to the Linux kernel. I've carefully reviewed the documentation and followed the submission guidelines. Looking forward to your feedback.

title: Update .cocciconfig
body: Reduce the default spatch --timeout from 200 seconds to 100 seconds to improve responsiveness, shorten feedback loops for developers, and lower CPU usage in CI by aborting long-running or stalled Coccinelle rules sooner. This stricter limit helps prevent individual SmPL scripts from blocking jobs for several minutes, encourages optimization and scope-limiting of patterns, and reduces the likelihood of unpredictable timeouts or resource contention in shared environments. Legitimate complex rules that require more time can still be run locally or in a dedicated CI job with a higher timeout, ensuring flexibility without keeping the higher default cost for all runs.

title: Rust kernel improvement
body:
This PR improves the Rust portion of the Linux kernel by:

- Marking `CStr::to_str` as `#[must_use]`, ensuring that callers handle potential UTF-8 conversion errors instead of ignoring them.
- Updating the documentation for `CStr::to_str` and `as_str_unchecked` to clarify safety requirements. `as_str_unchecked` now documents that the caller must ensure the underlying bytes are valid UTF-8.
- Replacing placeholder `SAFETY: TODO` comments in `rust/kernel/workqueue.rs` with detailed explanations of the safety invariants for `RawWorkItem` and `WorkItemPointer`.

These changes improve safety guarantees and documentation for users of the Rust kernel APIs.

title: Fix ARC700 mmap alignment and optimize content clipping workflow
body:
Fix ARC700 mmap cache alignment and improve content clipping workflow

Changes:
- Added SHMLBA alignment for shared mappings to prevent cache aliasing
- Implemented hook-first clip extraction with platform-native pacing
- Added automated trimming based on engagement points

Why:
ARC700 shared memory was hitting cache coherency issues causing data corruption. Content workflow needed better short-form optimization for modern platforms.

Result:
Reliable shared memory performance and streamlined content processing that scales across platforms.

title: ksmbd: prevent use-after-free in oplock/lease break ack error path
body:
This patch adds a null check for opinfo after opinfo_put() in the
error handling path of smb20_oplock_break_ack() and smb21_lease_break_ack().

Under certain failure conditions, the opinfo structure may be freed
before reaching the err_out: label, which would cause undefined
behavior if accessed.

This patch ensures that no further access is performed on opinfo if it has already been released.

Signed-off-by: LoboQ1ng <q1ngtse24@gmail.com>&Z1naX5 <zenaxu@hdu.edu.cn>

title: lklfuse: support exclusive locks to avoid duplicate mounts
body:
Duplicate mounts are a risk when running multiple lklfuse instances, as we don't have a single arbitrator to manage access. This patchset adds a new `lock` parameter, which can provide host-side `flock()` based exclusion.

```
The following changes since commit ac5cde6a24d2b7fa8613ca3bd51e6a5567fb5adc:

  Merge pull request #609 from ddiss/lklfuse_rst_manpage (2025-06-24 10:36:25 -0700)

are available in the Git repository at:

  https://github.com/ddiss/linux lklfuse_flock

for you to fetch changes up to 92ed6c47edaa8d639df427a6f2b00ba595443df7:

  lkl: tests: fix net setup_backend return status (2025-07-02 21:47:30 +1000)

----------------------------------------------------------------
David Disseldorp (4):

      lkl: systemd: use lklfuse lock parameter
      lkl: tests: add lklfuse_lock_conflict test
```

title: vsprintf: make vsnprintf() return total output length per POSIX
body:
The current implementation of vsnprintf() returns the number of characters
actually written to the output buffer (excluding the null terminator), which
does not comply with the POSIX specification.

POSIX requires vsnprintf() to return the number of characters that *would*
have been written, had the buffer been large enough. This is important so
callers can detect truncation.

This patch introduces a total_len counter that accurately tracks the intended
output length regardless of buffer size. The final return value is now
total_len instead of the number of characters that were successfully written.

This makes vsnprintf() standards-compliant while preserving existing
behavior for safely writing to bounded buffers.

Signed-off-by: Jake <jakecontactxyz@gmail.com)

title: Update free-space-tree.c
body: set_free_space_tree_thresholds calculates and assigns two critical thresholds‚Äîbitmap_high_thresh and bitmap_low_thresh‚Äîfor a given Btrfs block group. These thresholds determine when the filesystem should switch between two internal free-space representations: extent trees and bitmaps. Bitmaps become more space-efficient once the number of metadata items required to track free extents exceeds a certain point; these thresholds encode that decision logic.

title: fuse: Clarify offset field is signed despite uint64_t type
body: Add comment noting that the uint64_t offset in fuse_lseek_in is derived from kernel loff_t and should be treated as signed for negative offsets.
